elements.content: We report a trinuclear CoII complex containing bridging dicyanamides and a tris-chelated HAT, which possesses ∼37% void space. The magnetic exchange pathways appear in the structure as a corner sharing tetrahedral network. The compound crystallizes in the monoclinic space group P21/c [a = 13.655(3) Å, b = 15.189(3) Å, c = 22.367(4) Å, β = 114.100(2)°, V = 4234.5(14) Å3, Z = 4, R(F o) = 0.0823]. The magnetic data were fit to an S = 3/2 model for systems dominated by zero-field splitting effects with g = 2.01 and D = 38.9 cm-1.
elements.clean_text: We report a trinuclear CoII complex containing bridging dicyanamides and a tris-chelated HAT, which possesses ~37% void space. The magnetic exchange pathways appear in the structure as a corner sharing tetrahedral network. The compound crystallizes in the monoclinic space group P21/c [a = 13.655(3) Å, b = 15.189(3) Å, c = 22.367(4) Å, β = 114.100(2)°, V = 4234.5(14) Å3, Z = 4, R(F o) = 0.0823]. The magnetic data were fit to an S = 3/2 model for systems dominated by zero-field splitting effects with g = 2.01 and D = 38.9 cm-1.

elements.content: The reaction of CoII, tris-chelating 1,4,5,8,9,12-hexaazatriphenylene (HAT), and dicyanamide leads to Co3(HAT)[N(CN)2]6(OH2)2 possessing a corner sharing tetrahedral network structure. The magnetic properties are dominated by zero field splitting effects.
elements.clean_text: The reaction of CoII, tris-chelating 1,4,5,8,9,12-hexaazatriphenylene (HAT), and dicyanamide leads to Co3(HAT)[N(CN)2]6(OH2)2 possessing a corner sharing tetrahedral network structure. The magnetic properties are dominated by zero field splitting effects.

elements.content: The HAT (1,4,5,8,9,12-hexaazatriphenylene) ligand and its derivatives were originally viewed as being useful for studies of photophysical properties, liquid crystalline ordering, chirality, and DNA related chemistry. More recently, HAT has been adopted by chemists studying supermolecular materials, to create self-assembled, cagelike compounds, and by chemists studying magnetic materials, to probe for spin-frustrated or trimerlike behavior in systems containing metal ions.
elements.clean_text: The HAT (1,4,5,8,9,12-hexaazatriphenylene) ligand and its derivatives were originally viewed as being useful for studies of photophysical properties, liquid crystalline ordering, chirality, and DNA related chemistry. More recently, HAT has been adopted by chemists studying supermolecular materials, to create self-assembled, cagelike compounds, and by chemists studying magnetic materials, to probe for spin-frustrated or trimerlike behavior in systems containing metal ions.

elements.content:
<fig id="ic020176xf1" orientation="portrait" position="float">
<label></label>
<graphic orientation="portrait" position="float" xlink:href="ic020176xf1.tif"></graphic>
</fig>

The Dunbar group has used the HAT ligand to create molecular squares, in which the magnetic exchange was found to be weak, and HAT(CN)6 to make a magnetic material, [CuHAT(CN)6]∞, that orders as a canted antiferromagnet below 6 K. However, the only report of magnetic exchange mediated by HAT is that of Sletten and co-workers for CuII chains.
elements.clean_text: The Dunbar group has used the HAT ligand to create molecular squares, in which the magnetic exchange was found to be weak, and HAT(CN)6 to make a magnetic material, [CuHAT(CN)6]∞, that orders as a canted antiferromagnet below 6 K. However, the only report of magnetic exchange mediated by HAT is that of Sletten and co-workers for CuII chains.

elements.content: We previously reported a mixed-ligand material containing dicyanamide and 2,2‘-bipyrimidine that showed dimerlike behavior due to strong magnetic exchange through a bis-bidentate bipyrimidine ligand and very weak exchange through the μ1,5-dicyanamide ligands. We anticipated that a similar system incorporating dicyanamide and HAT might reveal trimerlike magnetic properties. The aqueous reaction of excess CoSO4, Na[N(CN)2], and HAT in a 6:6:1 ratio led to the isolation of red crystals that upon drying had the composition of CoII 3(HAT)[N(CN)2]6(OH2)2 based on elemental analysis, and herein, we report the structure and magnetic properties.
elements.clean_text: We previously reported a mixed-ligand material containing dicyanamide and 2,2‘-bipyrimidine that showed dimerlike behavior due to strong magnetic exchange through a bis-bidentate bipyrimidine ligand and very weak exchange through the μ1,5-dicyanamide ligands. We anticipated that a similar system incorporating dicyanamide and HAT might reveal trimerlike magnetic properties. The aqueous reaction of excess CoSO4, Na[N(CN)2], and HAT in a 6:6:1 ratio led to the isolation of red crystals that upon drying had the composition of CoII 3(HAT)[N(CN)2]6(OH2)2 based on elemental analysis, and herein, we report the structure and magnetic properties.

elements.content: Despite repeated and varied attempts, the largest high quality crystal found was 0.04 × 0.10 × 0.10 mm, which resulted in a very weak data set (av I/σ = 1.87), and the absence of high-angle data limits the resolution to about 1.2 Å. One of the central CNamide fragments in a [N(CN)2]- anion could not be located, although its position is unambiguously defined by the other atoms. The sixth dicyanamide fragment could not be located because of the poor data arising from the small crystal size, large amount of disordered water, and so forth. The crystallographic data were scrutinized for the possibilities that (a) the water molecules bound to Co(1) and Co(2) could be bridging dicyanamides and (b) the highly disordered dicyanamide fragment, [N(61)−C(62)···N(63)], could be two terminally bound and highly disordered dicyanamide anions. The first possibility was ruled out on the basis of typical Co−Nnitrile and Co···Co distances in known dicyanamide complexes. The second possibility led to poorer refinement statistics. Thus, the crystallographically determined formula is [CoII 3(HAT)[N(CN)2]5(OH2)2]+. However, the presence of a sixth [N(CN)2]- and divalent Co is supported by the elemental analysis and magnetic data as well as by the need for charge balance. The presence of the sixth dicyanamide as an unbound, highly disordered anion among the water molecules of the void spaces is supported by a υC ⋮ N absorption at 2133 cm-1. For comparison, [PPh4][N(CN)2], possessing unbound [N(CN)2]-, exhibits υC ⋮ N at 2227s, 2188s, and 2130s cm-1, while absorptions for Na[N(CN)2] possessing [N(CN)2]- bound to Na+ ions occur at 2288s, 2236s, 2228s, and 2181s cm-1 (Table S1).
elements.clean_text: Despite repeated and varied attempts, the largest high quality crystal found was 0.04 × 0.10 × 0.10 mm, which resulted in a very weak data set (av I/σ = 1.87), and the absence of high-angle data limits the resolution to about 1.2 Å. One of the central CNamide fragments in a [N(CN)2]- anion could not be located, although its position is unambiguously defined by the other atoms. The sixth dicyanamide fragment could not be located because of the poor data arising from the small crystal size, large amount of disordered water, and so forth. The crystallographic data were scrutinized for the possibilities that (a) the water molecules bound to Co(1) and Co(2) could be bridging dicyanamides and (b) the highly disordered dicyanamide fragment, [N(61)-C(62)⋅⋅⋅N(63)], could be two terminally bound and highly disordered dicyanamide anions. The first possibility was ruled out on the basis of typical Co-Nnitrile and Co⋅⋅⋅Co distances in known dicyanamide complexes. The second possibility led to poorer refinement statistics. Thus, the crystallographically determined formula is [CoII 3(HAT)[N(CN)2]5(OH2)2]+. However, the presence of a sixth [N(CN)2]- and divalent Co is supported by the elemental analysis and magnetic data as well as by the need for charge balance. The presence of the sixth dicyanamide as an unbound, highly disordered anion among the water molecules of the void spaces is supported by a υC ⋮ N absorption at 2133 cm-1. For comparison, [PPh4][N(CN)2], possessing unbound [N(CN)2]-, exhibits υC ⋮ N at 2227s, 2188s, and 2130s cm-1, while absorptions for Na[N(CN)2] possessing [N(CN)2]- bound to Na+ ions occur at 2288s, 2236s, 2228s, and 2181s cm-1 (Table S1).

elements.content: The program SQUEEZE was used to analyze the void spaces in the lattice for water molecules as well as unlocated [N(CN)2]- whose presence could not be determined directly. Two void spaces of equal volume (788 Å3) were located in the unit cell, each containing 246 e- (corresponding to ca. 24 water molecules) for a void-space count of 492 e-, or a [N(CN)2]- and nine water molecules per asymmetric (formula) unit not directly coordinated to Co. These void spaces correspond to approximately 37% of the total volume of the crystal, although the actual volume must be somewhat less because of the presence of crystallographically unlocated atoms. The occupation of this void space predominantly by unbound water could lead to the classification of this material as microporous, and it is interesting to note that the percentage of void space, 37%, in this material is identical to that found for [Co(HAT)Cl2]4.
elements.clean_text: The program SQUEEZE was used to analyze the void spaces in the lattice for water molecules as well as unlocated [N(CN)2]- whose presence could not be determined directly. Two void spaces of equal volume (788 Å3) were located in the unit cell, each containing 246 e- (corresponding to ca. 24 water molecules) for a void-space count of 492 e-, or a [N(CN)2]- and nine water molecules per asymmetric (formula) unit not directly coordinated to Co. These void spaces correspond to approximately 37% of the total volume of the crystal, although the actual volume must be somewhat less because of the presence of crystallographically unlocated atoms. The occupation of this void space predominantly by unbound water could lead to the classification of this material as microporous, and it is interesting to note that the percentage of void space, 37%, in this material is identical to that found for [Co(HAT)Cl2]4.

elements.content: Co3(HAT)[N(CN)2]6(OH2)2 is composed of trinuclear Co3(HAT) groups linked together by dicyanamide ligands (Figure ). There are two different octahedral CoII centers; Co(3) is coordinated to two N's from HAT and four nitrile N's from two μ1,5-dicyanamides, and Co(1) and Co(2) consisting of two N's from HAT, three N's from two μ1,5-dicyanamides, and one O from a bound water molecule. This corresponds to the formula of [Co3(HAT)[N(CN)2]5(OH2)2]+; however, elemental analysis, IR, and charge balance considerations indicate that a sixth dicyanamide anion is present.
elements.clean_text: Co3(HAT)[N(CN)2]6(OH2)2 is composed of trinuclear Co3(HAT) groups linked together by dicyanamide ligands (Figure ). There are two different octahedral CoII centers; Co(3) is coordinated to two N's from HAT and four nitrile N's from two μ1,5-dicyanamides, and Co(1) and Co(2) consisting of two N's from HAT, three N's from two μ1,5-dicyanamides, and one O from a bound water molecule. This corresponds to the formula of [Co3(HAT)[N(CN)2]5(OH2)2]+; however, elemental analysis, IR, and charge balance considerations indicate that a sixth dicyanamide anion is present.

elements.content: The CoII···N distances range from 2.033 to 2.215 Å. The C···N distances and angles of the dicyanamide and HAT ligands are consistent with previously reported structures. The Co3(HAT) moiety is an approximate equilateral triangle with Co···Co separations of 7.075(6), 7.113(6), and 7.146(6) Å, Figure b. Each HAT plane is then capped by a μ1,5-dicyanamide linked Co atom to create a corner sharing tetrahedral network (Figure ). The Co···Co separations through the μ-dicyanamides are 7.882(6), 7.893(6), and 7.911(6) Å and, hence, are ∼0.8 Å longer than the Co···Co separations via the HAT ligand.
elements.clean_text: The CoII⋅⋅⋅N distances range from 2.033 to 2.215 Å. The C⋅⋅⋅N distances and angles of the dicyanamide and HAT ligands are consistent with previously reported structures. The Co3(HAT) moiety is an approximate equilateral triangle with Co⋅⋅⋅Co separations of 7.075(6), 7.113(6), and 7.146(6) Å, Figure b. Each HAT plane is then capped by a μ1,5-dicyanamide linked Co atom to create a corner sharing tetrahedral network (Figure ). The Co⋅⋅⋅Co separations through the μ-dicyanamides are 7.882(6), 7.893(6), and 7.911(6) Å and, hence, are ~0.8 Å longer than the Co⋅⋅⋅Co separations via the HAT ligand.

elements.content: Schematic showing [Co3(HAT)[N(CN)2]5(OH2)2]+ with corner sharing tetrahedral network drawn. Average Co···Co separation within the HAT plane is 7.116 Å and between Co3HAT and the apex is 7.895 Å.
elements.clean_text: 2  Schematic showing [Co3(HAT)[N(CN)2]5(OH2)2]+ with corner sharing tetrahedral network drawn. Average Co⋅⋅⋅Co separation within the HAT plane is 7.116 Å and between Co3HAT and the apex is 7.895 Å.

elements.content: The reciprocal magnetic susceptibility, χ-1(T), and χT(T) between 2 and 300 K are shown in Figure . The room temperature χT value of 5.78 emu K mol-1 is consistent with that expected for three isolated S = 3/2 spin centers (i.e., 5.63 emu K mol-1). The close agreement between the experimental and expected room temperature χT(T) values suggests that there is very little spin−orbit coupling in this system. This observation is corroborated by a poor fit to an equation for 4T1g ions, which accounts for spin−orbit coupling. Instead, the data can be fit by an expression for S = 3/2 systems with dominant zero field splitting effects, D, eq 1−4: where N is Avogadro's number, μ B , the Bohr Magneton, k B, Boltzmann's constant, g, the Lande g value, and D, the zero field splitting, with g = 2.01 and D = 38.9 cm-1. There are surprisingly few quantitative reports of D in octahedral CoII complexes. However, D = 82.7 cm-1 was found for the highly tetragonally distorted six-coordinate complex Co(acac)2(H2O)2 (acac = acetylacetonate), while D = 53 cm-1 was observed for Co(pyridine-N-oxide)6[ClO4]2, which exhibits a slight (crystallographically unobservable) trigonal distortion. In the present system, Co(1) and Co(2) are highly trigonally distorted, and Co(3) contains two bonds, from NHAT, that are elongated relative to the other four Co(3)−N[N(CN 3 )] − bonds. If we consider the D in the present system as an average of two trigonally distorted metal centers (D = 53 cm-1) and one psuedotetrahedral metal center (D = −36 to +13 cm-1), D should range from 23.3 to 39.7 cm-1 in accord with observation. A molecular field approximation, eq 4, showed negligible intermolecular, zJ, interactions.

The room temperature χT value of 5.78 emu K mol-1 is consistent with that expected for three isolated S = 3/2 spin centers (i.e., 5.63 emu K mol-1). The close agreement between the experimental and expected room temperature χT(T) values suggests that there is very little spin-orbit coupling in this system. This observation is corroborated by a poor fit to an equation for 4T1g ions, which accounts for spin-orbit coupling. Instead, the data can be fit by an expression for S = 3/2 systems with dominant zero field splitting effects, D, eq 1-4:                where N is Avogadro's number, μ B , the Bohr Magneton, k B, Boltzmann's constant, g, the Lande g value, and D, the zero field splitting, with g = 2.01 and D = 38.9 cm-1. There are surprisingly few quantitative reports of D in octahedral CoII complexes. However, D = 82.7 cm-1 was found for the highly tetragonally distorted six-coordinate complex Co(acac)2(H2O)2 (acac = acetylacetonate), while D = 53 cm-1 was observed for Co(pyridine-N-oxide)6[ClO4]2, which exhibits a slight (crystallographically unobservable) trigonal distortion. In the present system, Co(1) and Co(2) are highly trigonally distorted, and Co(3) contains two bonds, from NHAT, that are elongated relative to the other four Co(3)-N[N(CN  3  )]  -  bonds. If we consider the D in the present system as an average of two trigonally distorted metal centers (D = 53 cm-1) and one psuedotetrahedral metal center (D = -36 to +13 cm-1), D should range from 23.3 to 39.7 cm-1 in accord with observation. A molecular field approximation, eq 4, showed negligible intermolecular, zJ, interactions.

elements.content: Temperature dependence of χ-1 (·) and χT (○) for Co3(HAT)[N(CN)2]6(OH2)2. Solid line represents fit to eq 3 with g = 2.01 and D = 38.9 cm-1.
elements.clean_text: 3  Temperature dependence of χ-1 (⋅) and χT (○) for Co3(HAT)[N(CN)2]6(OH2)2. Solid line represents fit to eq 3 with g = 2.01 and D = 38.9 cm-1.

elements.content: From a consideration of the structural framework, geometrically induced spin frustration is expected for triangular and tetrahedral arrays in which the spin bearing centers would like to couple antiferromagnetically. Figure a shows how one or more spin centers will be unable to satisfy the criteria for antiferromagnetic coupling.
elements.clean_text: From a consideration of the structural framework, geometrically induced spin frustration is expected for triangular and tetrahedral arrays in which the spin bearing centers would like to couple antiferromagnetically. Figure a shows how one or more spin centers will be unable to satisfy the criteria for antiferromagnetic coupling.

elements.content: Schematic showing (a) spin frustration in triangular and tetrahedral arrays and (b) the compromise spin states adopted by triangular and tetrahedral arrays.
elements.clean_text: 4  Schematic showing (a) spin frustration in triangular and tetrahedral arrays and (b) the compromise spin states adopted by triangular and tetrahedral arrays.

elements.content: To overcome this frustration, materials will often undergo a transition from a paramagnetic state to a noncollinear or compromise spin configuration (Figure b). When the unpaired electrons are aligned at 120° and 109° in the triangular and tetrahedral units, respectively, the overall spin vector is equal to zero as is required for antiferromagnetic coupling. Attempts to note the spin frustration via ac magnetic susceptibility and heat capacity measurements failed to reveal a magnetic phase transition down to 2 K.
elements.clean_text: To overcome this frustration, materials will often undergo a transition from a paramagnetic state to a noncollinear or compromise spin configuration (Figure b). When the unpaired electrons are aligned at 120° and 109° in the triangular and tetrahedral units, respectively, the overall spin vector is equal to zero as is required for antiferromagnetic coupling. Attempts to note the spin frustration via ac magnetic susceptibility and heat capacity measurements failed to reveal a magnetic phase transition down to 2 K.

elements.content: Co3(HAT)[N(CN)2]6(OH2)2 is a material with a large (∼37%) total void fraction and a unique structural motif. The structural motif consists of a corner sharing tetrahedral network ideal for spin frustration. However, the transition to a noncollinear or compromise spin state does not occur down above 2 K, and the magnetic data can be fit to an S = 3/2 model for systems dominated by zero-field splitting effects with g = 2.01 and D = 38.9 cm-1.
elements.clean_text: Co3(HAT)[N(CN)2]6(OH2)2 is a material with a large (~37%) total void fraction and a unique structural motif. The structural motif consists of a corner sharing tetrahedral network ideal for spin frustration. However, the transition to a noncollinear or compromise spin state does not occur down above 2 K, and the magnetic data can be fit to an S = 3/2 model for systems dominated by zero-field splitting effects with g = 2.01 and D = 38.9 cm-1.

elements.content: Stretching frequencies (νC ⋮ N) of dicyanamide reference compounds (Table S1), and the crystallographic data in CIF format. This material is available free of charge via the Internet at http://pubs.acs.org.

cln_elements.content: We report a trinuclear CoII complex containing bridging dicyanamides and a tris-chelated HAT, which possesses ∼37% void space. The magnetic exchange pathways appear in the structure as a corner sharing tetrahedral network. The compound crystallizes in the monoclinic space group P21/c [a = 13.655(3) Å, b = 15.189(3) Å, c = 22.367(4) Å, β = 114.100(2)°, V = 4234.5(14) Å3, Z = 4, R(F o) = 0.0823]. The magnetic data were fit to an S = 3/2 model for systems dominated by zero-field splitting effects with g = 2.01 and D = 38.9 cm-1.

metadata.title:
Corner Sharing Tetrahedral Network in Co3(HAT)[N(CN)2]6(OH2)2
(HAT = 1,4,5,8,9,12-Hexaazatriphenylene)
